newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX complex gains as gasoline leads the way.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX complex gains as gasoline leads the way.

text.p: Crude oil futures rose sharply Thursday in a largely technical move, sparked by indications gasoline demand was firming up ahead of the Memorial Day weekend at the end of May.
Gasoline futures for June delivery rose 1.58 cents to 62.50 cents a gallon. June crude futures rose 72 cents to $20.34 a barrel.
Heating oil June futures gained 1.3 cents to settle at 54.38 cents a gallon.

"Basically, I think a lot of traders were looking at the 59.25 level (for gasoline), where 'buy' support held," said Gerry Samuels a trader for ARB Oil in California. "But we've been in a very wide and choppy range for a month and a half...(and) even with today's activity we didn't have a difinitive breakout."
The same view of the market was echoed by other traders and analysts.
"I don't see this as a major technical breakout at this point," said a Texas trader. "So far, we're still stuck in the ranges (and for future direction) I'm guessing 'down' in the long term."

The gasoline move started on Wednesday after Department of Energy figures showed a big dip in stocks, which sent prices up and triggered stop-less 'buy' orders, traders said. That buying carried through in Thursday's market, though there was little evidence in the cash market of a strong seasonal uptick in buying, according to traders of physical gasoline.
There was little fundamental news to give the market clear direction, traders said.

Several of the seven OPEC oil ministers at an oil conference in Iran -- though not all-important Saudi Arabia, nor Iraq, United Arab Emirates, Algeria -- renewed their call for quota compliance on Thursday.

However, one of the ministers calling for quota compliance was Nigeria, one of the biggest cheaters with production in April over 2.11 million bpd in April, compared with a quota of 1.865 million bpd, according to a Reuter survey of oil companies and industry analysts.
"I can't remember a time in the last few years when there has been less fundamental news to give the market clear direction," said Samuels of ARB.

There was no suggestion from the OPEC ministers of substantive action to be taken to enforce quota compliance and several ministers said they expect a rollover of the official 25.03 million bpd OPEC ceiling when the ministers next meet on June 25.
The Reuter survey estimated wellhead production by OPEC in April at 27.05 million bpd.
